choices.C: Events where values of field A are equal to values of field B.
choices.B: Events that contain the string value A=B.
choices.A: Events where field A contains the string value B.
choices.D: Events that contain the string value where A=B.

discussion.content: Where command interprets unquoted or single-quoted strings as fields and double quoted strings as "field vales," which mean A=B, in this case, is comparing fields to a field.

Selected Answer: C
Just tested where 2 values A=B and they returned the ones with the same value (if A=3 and B=3 then that would show in the results)

questions.question_text: What are the expected results for a search that contains the command | where A=B?
Which of these stats commands will show the total bytes for each unique combination of page and server?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D IS CORRECT
Explanation:
A. index=web | stats sum(bytes) BY values(page) values(server): This is incorrect because using values in this context is not necessary for summing by page and server.

B. index=web | stats sum(bytes) BY page AND server: This is incorrect syntax. You cannot use AND in the BY clause for the stats command.

C. index=web | stats sum(bytes) BY page BY server: This is incorrect syntax. You should only use one BY to specify multiple fields together.

D. index=web | stats sum(bytes) BY page server: This is correct. This command effectively sums the bytes for each unique combination of page and server.

Therefore, the correct answer is D. index=web | stats sum(bytes) BY page server.

Copy
Regenerate

choices.D: index=web | stats sum(bytes) BY page server
choices.A: index=web | stats sum(bytes) BY values(page) values(server)
choices.C: index=web | stats sum(bytes) BY page BY server
choices.B: index=web | stats sum(bytes) BY page AND server

questions.question_text: When would a user select delimited field extractions using the Field Extractor (FX)?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Same delimiter character play a role

choices.C: When a log file has values that are separated by the same character, for example, commas.
choices.D: When a log file contains empty lines or comments.
choices.B: When the file has a header that might provide information about its structure or format.
choices.A: With structured files such as JSON or XML.

questions.question_text: To which of the following can a field alias be applied?

choices.B: Data found in a lookup table.
choices.D: Only one single field in a dataset.
choices.A: A given host, source, or sourcetype.
choices.C: Either a calculated field or an extracted field.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Correct answer is A: calculated fields and lookups happen later in the cycle. See:
https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/9.4.0/Knowledge/Addaliasestofields

Selected Answer: A
drop-down has 3 types.sourcetype source host.

Selected Answer: A
The correct answer is A. When you create a field alias, the Apply To drop-down box allows you to select SourceType, Source, or Host.
